Quote: I know what's wrong with it. It's a Ford. You know what they say Ford stands for, don't ya? It stands for 'Fix it again, Tony'.
You're thinking of a Fiat, Dale.
"Fix... it... again..."
Whatcha listenin' to, son?
I don't think you'd like it.
Well, why not? I like this new generation of music. [puts headphones on]
Hello?
[takes headphones off] Mother of God, it's all toilet sounds! Where did you record this?
I bought it at the mall! It's the Funny Phone Jerks!
Let me tell you, Bobby, there's nothing "funny" about these sounds! What that person on your tape has is a medical disorder. Now you get ready for the game, OK?
Yes, sir.
[leaving Bobby's room] That boy ain't right.
So, are you ready to kick some Wildcat butt, Bobby?
Okay.
Nah, don't you worry, son. You just do your best.
Don't listen to her, Bobby. If you wanna win, you're gonna have to do better than your best.
How do I do that?
You gotta give a hundred and ten percent. That's what'll give you that winnin' edge.
But what if the Wildcats give a hundred and ten percent, too?
Well, then you gotta try even harder.
How about if Bobby gave a hundred and twelve percent?
Ahm ... sure, that'd work.
Or maybe a hundred and thirteen?
[Annoyed] Yeah, yeah, that's even better.
No, uh, I don't know. Thirteen is a very unlucky number.
Look, we're not talking about thirteen. We're talking about a hundred and thirteen, and even ... uh ... okay, give a hundred and twelve, what's the difference? Look, Bobby. Just do your best, okay?
Excuse me, where's the hardware department?
[Clueless] Where is the hardware department? Uhm, hm, what exactly is it you're looking for?
The hardware department.
Yeah, but are you looking for like a tool or something?
What difference does it make?
Huh, what difference does it make?
Okay, I'm lookin' for a tap-and-die and some WD-40.
Huh, what is it that you're trying to do?
[Losing patience] I'm tryin' to buy a tap-and-die and some WD-40 and get out of this God-forsaken store!
Uh ... and what is a tap-and-die?
Okay, forget it! Let's say I want a hammer. Do you know what a hammer is? That's what I want, a damned hammer! Now where in the hell would I go?
Hey, that's that Hank Hill fella that lives on the block next to us.
He sure has a temper, doesn't he?
Sure does. Makes you wonder who gave his boy that black eye.
You're gonna have to pay for that, dude.
[Shouting] You're fired!
[referring to the sound of Bobby throwing a baseball at the living room wall] Dammit! There it is again! Where is that thumpin' comin' from? It's drivin' me crazy!
Could be far-off helicopters... U.N. helicopters.
Dale! What're you doin'? Give me some light! Now! I can't see! (Hank drops his wrench) Ow, my arm! (The hood closes) Ow, my head!
Mr. Hill, I feel that you're coming from an anger mindset, and if you're projecting this anger onto me, it gives me grave concerns as to how you facilitate your son's growth in private.
Mister, I have not begun to project my anger onto you!

Now you listen to me, mister. I work for a livin', and I mean real work, not writin' down gobbledegook! I provide the people of this community with propane and propane accessories. Oh, when I think of all my hard earned tax dollars goin' ta pay a bunch of little twig-boy bureaucrats like you, it just makes me wanna ... oh ... oh God ... it just ...
Hank?
Honey, bring me my BC headache powder and a glass of water.
Alright, Hank.

Now you listen here. You see that boy? That's my boy! And if you ever try to take him away, so help me God, I'll tear ya a new one bigger'n the Grand Canyon! Now I want you to get out of my house, yer not welcome here! I mean now, before I give you a black eye! Git!
I'm gonna help get him this alternator off. (Dale cuts a wire).
Ah, Dale, I think ya released the brake cable! Dale?

No, I didn't. (The truck crashes into the garage door). I guess I'd better get goin', ah, I got some edging to do. (Dale grabs his cap out of the engine and he, along with Bill and Boomhauer, run back to their homes).
How is cutting down on pollution a government plot, Dale?
Open up your eyes, man. They're trying to control global warming. Get it? GLO-BAL.
So what?

That's code for U.N. commissars telling Americans what the temperature's going to be in their outdoors. I say let the world warm up, see what Boutros Boutros-Ghali-Ghali thinks about that! We'll grow oranges in Alaska.
Dale, you giblet-head, we live in Texas. It's already 110° in the summer, and if it gets one degree hotter, I'm gonna kick your ass!
Bobby, you can't make an omelette without breakin' eggs, and you can't get on base without takin' a swing.
The pitcher could walk me, couldn't he?
Don't play lawyer-ball, son.

[discussing Seinfeld] See that part where dang ol' George come in there, he talks 'bout tastin' his own burp and Kramer comes slidin' in there just like he always does.  I tell ya what, man, them dang ol' New York boys, just a show about nothin'.
(Mocking his dad) Git out my house! My boy ain't much, but he's all I got!
(Hank is lying on the bed) It's hard, Peggy. I don't wanna lose my little boy. My only son. But, oh, it's hard.
Well, you can relax. The investigation has been off for a week, only Bobby didn't tell us.
I'LL KILL HIM!!!!!
Alright, calm down, honey. Now, let me explain. He didn't do it to be mean, Bobby honestly doesn't think you love him all the time.
That's crazy, 'Course I love him.
Very good. Now, say it to Bobby.
What are you talkin' about?
I want you to tell Bobby that your love for him is unconditional.
Well, I can't say that. I can't! You know how I was raised! What my father's like!
(shown in a flashback to Hank's youth) I got my shins blowed off by a Japanman's machine gun, so don't come cryin' to me with your problems!
Honey, I'm begging you. For the sake of this family, you have got to do it. He's waiting for you out on the porch.
Ah, jeez. Twig-boy coming over here... (Hank goes outside and talks to Bobby) Uh, you, uh, you're my son, uh, well, you know with everything uh, that entails, uh...
Uh-huh.
Uh, huh, you know, uh, feelings of, uh, fondness, and more, uh, heh, uh, you know what I mean, don't you, boy?
No.

Uhh, well uh, (Hank makes a weird sound) Huh, that's a hell of a weird sound, I've never made that before. Uh, I, you, uh, family. You're not making this easy on me, boy. (sighs) Okay, I love you no matter what you do. There, phew, let's go get something to eat.
I'm not, just a big disappointment to you?
Disappointment? No, you make me proud. I've been disappointed by just about everything else in this town, but you? Not once. Dammit, you're my boy. Heh, you know better than that. (Bobby laughing)
He punched him! I, I knew it! I told them! Did-did you see that?
See what, twig-boy?
(sighs) Never mind.

Character: Peggy is attempting to say the names of reproductive organs for a sexual education class.

Quote: Happiness. Happ-i-ness. Ha-penis. Penis. I did it! Ovaries. Uvula. Uterus. VAAAGINA!

Character: [Hank does a spit-take with his beer.]

Quote: Hey Hank, I just said...
I heard ya! The whole neighborhood can hear you cussing!
It's not cussing Hank, to say the name of a god-given body part.
Well it is if it's the part of a body that was meant to be concealed by an undergarment. You're dealing with organs that people just don't want to know about.
Well, Bobby ought to know about 'em. We don't want him growing up as repressed as we did.
Sure we do. I'm drawing the line here, Peggy. My son is not gonna learn this crazy crap! It says right here that he can't take the class without permission from both his parents!
Now, just hold on. Are you saying I'm not good enough to teach my own son?!
If you do not approve, you do not have to sign, and I do not approve. Permission denied!
Now, Bobby, you may have noticed that there is a difference between a man and a woman.
...a rather obvious difference.
You mean the penis?
You don't know who I am, but I know where you live and you better cut it out if you know what's good for you. Oh, and Hank, we changed that tee-off time to 3:00.
[As a child] When I grow up, I want to sell propane and propane accessories, if my grades are good enough!

We of the Order of the Straight Arrow call upon the spirit Wematanye, protector of the sacred ground that brings us cool water to drink and energy-efficient clean-burning propane gas for all our sacred heating and cooking needs. Wematanye says, respect the earth! She's ours, by God, our taxes pay for Her. Also, it says here you gotta love all Her creatures. Let's see...oh, here we go: Though we walk through the valley of the shadow of death, you're gonna recommend us to the spirit in the sky, with liberty and justice for all. Wematanye is with you, and with Texas. Amen.
Santa Claus is for babies!
[sad] You're a mean one, Mr. Grinch!
Your heart is telling you?!  Who's the boss, you or your heart?  You are!  Your heart is your employee!  So get your heart off its butt and back to work!
He looks like an angel. A dead angel.
(crying) Why, man, dang ol' why, why?!
It should have been Bill!
Oh, Hank. We never got a chance to talk about your problem. And now... we never will.
Remember, early detection is the key. Now pass in your algebra homework.
Goodbye, boy. See you in HELL!
(on TV) The temperature is a pleasant 70 degrees. And on a more personal note, I'd like to wish my friend Hank Hill a quick recovery from his embarrassing consti-
-pation.
(While constipated and watching his dog poo outside) Showoff.
"Don't touch me. I'm on the John."

You might have noticed in tonight's episode, there is some brief nudity. Now, as an actor, I only do nudity when I feel the script warrants it. And I thought tonight's episode only warranted seeing the side of my rump. You can believe me when I tell you the Fox executives were pushing for a whole lot more. If any of you were offended by my body, I'm truly sorry. Good night.
What the hell kind of country is this where I can only hate a man if he's white?
Do you... do you think my feet are too big, Hank?
No, hon. Just... more of you to love.
Ow.
Oh, sorry.
Kahn, please. For once try not to piss off neighbor. We kicked out of Laos, we kicked out of Anaheim... I tired of running.
So are you Chinese or Japanese?
I live in California last twenty year, but, ah... first come from Laos.
Huh?
Laos. We Laotian.
The ocean? What ocean?
We are Laotian--from Laos, stupid! It's a landlocked country in southeast Asia. It's between Vietnam and Thailand, OK? Population 4.7 million.
So are you Chinese or Japanese?
[groans]
He thinks just 'cause I'm from Texas that means I'm a redneck. Chinese people and their stupid stereotypes!
Please, Kahn. You're burning them! That's too much char.
Shut mouth and open mouth.
They'll probably get you with a blow-dart; that's their way. But you'll just think its a mosquito bite until you die, then you'll know the truth.
I could just stay home, order a bucket of chicken and watch Hee Haw; same thing [as going to the Hills' for dinner].
You know Kahn, we may deny our kids completely different deserts, but they both go to bed hungry, and that's what really matters.
Rabbit, you rednecks will eat anything!
Bobby, I'm proud of what you did at school today....So I'm buyin' you a hooker! Go ahead pick yourself out a live one.
Well, you know me-- I'm larger than life.

Character: Cotton tells the story of how he was injured in WWII

"I was 14, just a little older than Bobby. But I knew Uncle Sam needed me, so I lied and signed up. We had beat the Nazzys in Italy, and they shipped me to the Pacific theater. A Tojo torpedo sent our troop ship to the bottom. I could only save three of my buddies
Quote: Fatty, Stinky, and Brooklyn. They were kind of like you fellas [to Bill, Dale, and Boomhauer], only one of them was from Brooklyn. Out of the sun came a Tojo Zero and put fitty bullets in my back. The blood attracted sharks. I had to give 'em Fatty. Then things took a turn for the worse. I made it to an island, but it was full of Tojos! They were spitting on the U.S. flag! So I rushed 'em, but it was a trap. They opened fire and blew my shins off. Last thing I remember, I beat 'em all to death with a big piece of Fatty. I woke up in a field hospital, and they were sewing my feet to my knees."
[Speaking to Joseph about Connie]: Oow. She's moody. Must be PBS.
[to Luanne] You will never know if you are attractive. It's up to a man to tell you that. You keep eating, and I'll tell you when to stop.
Touch me again, and you'll be wearing that cornpone, old man.
Hoo-wee! Fiesty!
Dallas? I don't want you going to Dallas at all! That place is crawling with crack heads and debutantes. And half of them play for the Cowboys.
Now you listen to me! THE NAME IS HANK HILL! MR. HANK HILL! PEGGY MARRIED ME! I DIDN'T MARRY HER! What are you looking at?!
[crying] I am so stupid!
Aw, you're not stupid. Heck, you're smarter than me.
Oh, big deal!
Well, you're smarter than anyone else in Arlen.
Well, whoop-dee-do! I am the smartest hillbilly in Hillbillytown!
I-I'm trying Peggy. I just... hey, you know, Coachs used to say something that would fire us up when we were behind.
Yeah, what?
LOSER! YOU'RE A LOSER! ARE YOU FEELING SORRY FOR YOURSELF?! WELL, YOU SHOULD BE CAUSE YOU ARE DIRT! YOU MAKE ME SICK YOU BIG BABY! BABY WANT A BOTTLE?! A BIG DIRT BOTTLE?!
[crying harder] Why are you yelling at me?
Uh, well, I'm trying to be your coach. I... It's... It's inspiring.
Well, thank you, cause I feel worse than ever.
Well, it worked for the team.
No, It didn't. You went to State and lost.
Ah, jeez. I think I need one of those $8 beers.
: Thank you for Boggle lesson, Peggy Hill. Maybe next weekend I teach you mahjong. Bring your checkbook!
Man that dang 'ol piece of crap dang 'ol blocked up. G-get grass out there that-- [realizes his fingers have been chopped off in the game] AHH! I GOT NO FINGERS!
Is this John occupied? Esta es Juan occupado?
Sí.
Bobby?
Joseph, I understand you smoked your first cigarette today.
Dad, I'm sorry! I'll never smoke again.

Whoa, hold on, son! I want you to keep an open mind so you can make an informed decision. If you want, you can read a bloated government report on smoking or go straight to the horse's mouth and get the facts from the tobacco industry!
For God's sakes, Bobby, what nationality are you?
American.
Then why are you holding your cigarette like some kind of European Nazi in a movie?
Why does it matter?
That's not the right sort of attitude for you to have. Whatever you do, you should do right, even if it's something wrong.
Uh, I got to go do some stuff. I think I might have left the blender on.
[to Bobby] Only trailer trash smoke nowadays. Do you wanna look like trailer trash?
[crying] That's not fair! I don't smoke! [she runs away in tears]
Oh, honey, you are not trash just 'cause you grew up in a trailer and your mama's in prison.
Uh, Hank, there is a "tile" in the bathroom that I think we missed.
Really? Well, I better check that out.
Heh-heh-heh. Well, I found the "tile" — thank you very much, Peggy — and I looked at it but there's still some more "tile" for you to look at.
You know, I think I will save the rest of my "tile" for after breakfast.
Will you stop talking about your stupid tile?! If it's so dirty go clean it, and if it's clean you can shut up!!
[at a cold turkey support group meeting, glaring at the counselor] I got the strangest feeling someone's gonna kick his ass.
Hey, there, why don't you tell us your name and how long you've been smoking.
Uh, I'd rather not.
I understand. It's not easy to admit we're weak.
You're calling me weak?!? Look at your little birdy arms, they're no thicker than a cigarette! I could smoke them little arms!
Is this your son? It's beautiful how you came out to support your daddy.
I'm a smoker, too.
Oh, no. How long have you been addicted to cigarettes?
Since my dad let me smoke a whole carton.
Wait a minute, I didn't let him, I made him. It was a punishment.
Can I get a new buddy?
What is wrong with him?
You are sick, sir! You shouldn't be allowed to have children!

Now hold on a minute here. I didn't bring my family here to be yelled at. I don't think I like this club. You all whine too much, and the coffee's bad. I'll tell you what you need to do. You need to take a thirteenth step... down off your high horse!
Here's to three of the bravest individuals in all of Arlen. To the Hills and their tobacco-free future!
My God, are you still talking?!
Why's my potato got skin on it? I hate skin!
I will not sit here and have my work insulted! What, do you think the potatoes just fly into the bowl and mash themselves?!!
I know y'all don't mean none of those harsh words. It's just the nicotine withdrawal.
Why is she still talking?!!
[after finding Peggy hiding in the closet with a cigarette] I found her.
Close the damn door!! Can't you see that I am knitting!!
Mom. Hand over the cigarette!
Nooooo!
Mom this is not your son, this is your buddy!
NOOOOO!!
Hand it over!!

[locking the family in the bedroom] I'm crating ya'll in like an unruly dog. I am sick of dysfunctional families. I came from one, and I am not gonna let it happen to you. Function!! Function damn you!!!
Okay. Women and children first. I take the first puff, Bobby here get's the second, if there's anything left...you.
Who are you trying to kid? We all know there won't be anything left. Lets you and me split it Peg! It'll be romantic! You know like the old days, before he came along!
Momma. It's your son. Nine months inside remember? Those were good times too!
I don't know. Now this is just happening too fast, I just don't know.
Well I do! Come on Bobby, you and I can take her! You go high, I'll go low!

Well, look at us. At each other's throats. And after all we've been through. This family has survived fires and twisters and every strain of flu the Orient could throw at us. Well, we are not going to be done in by a lousy tobacco leaf. We're gonna make it. Together.

Put on shoes, hillbilly!
Where I come from we got this thing called karma. You do something bad, it come back and bite you in the ass!  Big, white, stubborn ass!
(Hypnotized by the Queen)...YES... ...MY... ...QUEEN...
(on his mower, talking to an anthill) Put your head between your six legs and kiss your butt good-bye! (runs over the anthill)
[After just noticing Dale] DALE!
Dale you went too far this time! Come back here! [Starts chasing Dale] Come here! I'm gonna kick your ass!
No! NO!
I'm gonna kick it harder if you don't come over here!
[desperate] You shouldn't have fired me! You know what I'm like! I'm capable of any crazy thing!

I had no choice! I tried planting the ants in your driveway, but they didn't take! They couldn't bite through cement! They're weak, like me! [Wheezes]
Dad?

You gave your life to save my son. I guess that makes us even for you ruinin' my lawn. What am I saying? Of course, it makes us even!
(Talking to a mannequin head) "You look really special tonight."
We'll move to Berlin. Bobby will be accepted there. I read somewhere that Germans are a very tolerant people. Their culture admires all kinds of freaks.
I know it is not my fault. If anything, this is your fault. You made him go to that camp with no toilet doors.

Don't point your finger at me, woman. You're the one who parks him in front of the TV and makes him watch all them Muppets. They got frogs kissing pigs, what the hell did they think was going to happen?
(Seeing Bobby freeing the mannequin head in the cabinets) Well that just tears it! I have tried to be patient, but now it's time for a little tough love! (snatches the mannequin head away from Bobby)
Wow, I always thought this was a crack house.
This gun is very nice.
Yeah, they’re all nice guns and all guns are nice.
Can I put a gun rack on my bike?

Why don't we get you into one of those safety courses and if you're still interested after they've taken all the fun out of it, then we'll see about the ponchos and the... uh... tournament.
Guns don't kill people, the government does.
Sorry I'm late, I had to stop at the wax museum and give the finger to F.D.R.
Six AM and already the boy ain't right...
Don't play mind checkers with me, man.  I'm not in the mood.
This tornado's already registered a level two on the Fujisaki scale. A storm that strong will send an egg through a barn door -- two barn doors if one of them's open.
What about a level three, Mr. Gribble?
A level three tornado will blow an egg right through a brick wall. Twister chasers call it "Humpty's Revenge."

All right, twister. It's just you and me now. Ten years ago you took my shed. [the twister's image is reflected on his shades] Did you think I'd forget that? Come on, bring it on! [a raindrop hits the windshield] GAAHH!! No! Please, let me go! [Dale panics, and the Dead Bug veers out of control]
Come on. [honks horn] Come on! Let's go! Move that truck! [a worker walks towards his truck] My wife is stuck in Shining Pines.
I'm not authorized to drive the truck, sir.
My wife is in danger, damn it! Now make something happen!
[blows whistle] SECURITY!!!
Bill, thank God! Make this idiot let me pass.
What did I do to deserve this? I didn't mean to curse my wife to Hell!
[worried] Ohh...
This is the chance I've been waiting for!
You're tough, Bill. You're the toughest Army barber I know.
Set your mousse to stun, there, Bill.
Mention your home was destroyed, and get a free 5-pound bag of onions.
Fine. But I think you owe my lawn an apology. *pauses* We're waiting!
Booooo! I am a high-priced Washington lobbyist, peddling influence! Who wants candy?
Luanne and Bobby are at Junie Harper's house
[Nearly chokes on his beer before swallowing] I came very close to spitting out beer!
[To Luanne] Just when I think you've said the stupidest thing ever, you keep talkin'!
Halloween is a satanic holiday. It was invented by the Dru-ish.
Maybe I should tie the long hair on your head to the short hair on your ass and kick you down the street!
Dale, you giblet-head, if you were gonna cheat, why'd you buy a frozen bass?
I had a coupon.
Are you taking me to the vet?

Dad, a man took pictures of me!
(finding Luanne in bed with Buckley) I'm in a crisis situation here, I gotta go find Bobby. You two take turns kicking each other's asses.
I thought we agreed to never discuss the horrors we saw on the killing fields of the Family Fun Center.
I don't care how many guys you held in the men's room, you still can't beat us!
This is a great Xerox of you!
Hey his scoop's bigger.
And there's doodies in there, right!?
(Shouting to Bobby stumbling around on the roof) It's a roof! Not American Bandstand!
When I need to correct Joseph, I tell him he's adopted.
Did a woman ruin the Supreme Court?

No, Bobby. You don't...
Gotcha!

Shouldn't you be teaching the girls about their monthlies?
I wanna go to a party school! Yeah, Chico State!
Some of the older ones have some breasts!
Hey, Bobby, if you don't beat Connie, we don't know what we'll do. So you better beat her!
I'm all for lady's wrestling. Except when they do it in pudding. That's just demeaning to the human beings who make pudding.
(Stereotypical Yiddish accent) Blind he's gone now!
Where's my finger?
Are you a war hero like my biological grandfather?
That is so Arizona!
There's a uh, what are those things called?--A semi, a demi, a coupla'-dozen-wheelers.
I would never join a religion that restricted my diet. I don't want to get into heaven that way.
It seems the other eye compensates by shutting itself down. It's one of nature's wonders.
I'm not gonna be blind forever you know. And the second I see some ass I'm kicking it. Now no more making fun of my blindness.
Okey-doke. Bring! Bring! Phone for you, Hank [takes off shoe and gives it to Hank]
The joke's on you, funny man.
OK Luanne, how do they get out of the closet? (gasps) Ohhh, No, that won't work.
(whispers) Jimmy the lock with a coat-hanger.

(whispers) Jimmy the lock with a... (sighs) uh, (out loud) I'll save you, Manger Babies.
You will?

(as the Manger Babies) We're free, we're free, whoo.
Thank you, assistant manager. Me-how can we ever repay you?
By never forgetting this lesson. Sneaking into the movies is wrong. As wrong as spilling juice on a new carpet.
Bravo, bravo.

You know Luanne really shouldn't waste this kind of talent on church. If you want, I could show this tape to my boss at channel 84. He's always looking for quality children's programming and home videos of things blowing up.
Well, Luanne really could use a boost right now, but I could not take advantage of our friendship like that, no.
Oh, Peggy, honey. This is show business. That's what friends do.
Suffering is a part of every religion, Peggy. I mean ... look at what the Jews have been through, and you never hear them complaining.
Hey Vickers, who do you like for the Super Bowl next year? The Doopie Loopies or the Shimmie Shammies?
Okay, okay, very funny. But I like the Bills.
Got-dangit Hank, I'm having an infarction!

Listen up, we are a family, and the daddy ain't feeling so good. Ladies, I got a shot coming. If you girls would please step outside? It is rude for such pretty gals like you to have to see my bare bottom.
OK, now that the skirts are out in the hallway we can get down to business. Hank, you are my right hand man, and I need you to take on this important job.
Yes, sir?
I need you to feed my hounds.
Uh, sir?
Tell them that you will love them! Vickers, you run the company, whole shebang.
Yes, sir!
Let's see what that fancy business school degree of yours is worth.
Sir, I fail to see what a business degree has over my 15 years of service to Strickland Propane!
I let you light the torch, didn't I? Right now my hounds are starving!
Here's key. Lock little sticky. You got to rake it like there's no tomorrow.
This is a car key.
Yeah, you win new car. This big game show. Just rake it stupid.
You will pay the condo manager 8,000 pesos.
But if the key does fit then you must acquit--.
10,000 pesos. Baliff, confiscate their identification.
Now just follow my lead and play it cool.
What if they find Kahn?
If I know my Mexican legal system, which I do, we'll get about 15 years with a starvation diet of moldy bread and warm water.
Distilled water?
(chuckling): No. And of course there is a total lack of toilet paper...and privacy.
Oh, God, I can't go while people watch.
Then let me do the talking.
Morning. Where are you gentlemen from?
(voice breaking): Arlen, Texas.
I've been to Arlen. Nice town.
Run!
I think we lost them. We'll be okay.
Okay?! We're screwed!
No, we're American. We got to find a pay phone and hope Ross Perot's 800 number's still working.
Why you want to call that nut for? Border right there. Millions of people cross over every day. We can, too. No big deal.
Illegally? No! America is my country and I love her. I wouldn't enter her in any way that's unnatural.
We have no choice, Hank. The I.N.S. had their cameras trained on us. The border guards think we're smugglers. I'm too pretty to go to jail!
It says here I owe $40 and that can't be true. I always bring back my tapes. Look for yourself, I've returned The Great Santini 23 times.
